entries: {@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 2 {@item Dagger|XPHB|Daggers}, {@item Divination Focus|DDFateWeaver}, {@item Dungeoneer's Pack|XPHB}, and 28 GP; or (B) 50 GP

Fate Weavers can bend and warp the threads that bind reality together, granting them the power to change the destiny of themselves and everyone around them. These threads, the so-called {@i 'threads of fate'}, form the underlying structure of the multiverse. Some represent creatures, places, or objects and tell the stories of their journeys through reality, while others represent the bonds between those things. They intertwine and influence each other’s paths as time marches from future to present to past.

The past is a tightly woven tapestry—an impossibly intricate ledger of {@i everything} that has ever happened. The future is a web of possibility—a forest of branching threads that represent every possible outcome simultaneously. The present is where a Fate Weaver does their work: tugging the threads to favor branches that realize their desires and avoid those that spell doom.

Fate Weavers are so rare as to be practically unheard of, and they can come about in many ways. Some are simply gifted from birth, some become connected to the threads through a profound act of magic, and some are granted knowledge through contact with a being of immense power. Whatever their origin, most Fate Weavers find that dodging the call to adventure is futile. After all, it’s hard to avoid destiny when you’re the one pulling the strings.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By manipulating the threads that hold the world together, you can cast spells. See chapter 7 for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules with Fate Weaver spells, which appear in the {@filter Fate Weaver spell list|spells|class=Fate Weaver (FW:R)} later in the class's description.

entries.name: Cantrips.
entries: You know three Fate Weaver cantrips of your choice. {@spell Guidance|xphb}, {@spell Prestidigitation|xphb}, and {@spell Sacred Flame|xphb} are recommended. Whenever you finish a Long Rest, you can replace one of your cantrips from this feature with another Fate Weaver cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Fate Weaver levels 4 and 10, you learn another Fate Weaver cantrip of your choice, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Fate Weaver Features table.

entries.name: Spell Slots.
entries: The Fate Weaver Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+.
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 Fate Weaver spells. {@spell Guiding Bolt|xphb}, {@spell Healing Word|xphb}, {@spell Mage Armor|xphb}, and {@spell Shield|xphb} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Fate Weaver levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Fate Weaver Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Fate Weaver spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Fate Weaver Features table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Fate Weaver, your list of prepared spells can include six Fate Weaver spells of level 1 or 2 in any combination.

If another Fate Weaver feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Fate Weaver spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells.
entries: Whenever you finish a Long Rest, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing any of the spells there with other Fate Weaver spells for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability.
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Fate Weaver spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus.
entries: You can use an {@item Arcane Focus|xphb} or a {@item Divination Focus|DDFateWeaver} as a Spellcasting Focus for your Fate Weaver spells.

classFeature.name: Fate Weaving
entries: You have learned how to pull at the threads that underlie reality to nudge any situation toward your desired outcome. Your ability to bend fate is represented by a pool of special dice called Fate Dice. You can use these dice to fuel the following option, and you gain additional uses for them as you level up.

entries.name: Favor and Folly.
entries: Immediately after another creature you within 30 feet of you rolls the d20 for a D20 Test, you can take a Reaction to expend 1 Fate Die and roll it, then apply the number rolled as a bonus or penalty (your choice) to the d20 roll.

entries.name: Fate Dice Pool.
entries: You have 2 Fate Dice, which are d4s. A Fate Die is expended when you use it. You regain all expended Fate Dice when you finish a Long Rest. You gain additional Fate Dice based on your level, as shown in the Dice Pool column of the Fate Weaver Features table.

entries.name: At Higher Levels.
entries: Your Fate Die changes when you reach certain Fate Weaver levels, as shown in the Fate Die column of the Fate Weaver Features table. The die becomes a d6 at level 5, a d8 at level 10, a d10 at level 15, and a d12 at level 20.

classFeature.name: Boon of Fate
entries: Your mere existence in the world makes reality malleable, and with your guidance, others around you can bend their own fate. As a Magic action, you can expend two Fate Dice to give a Boon of Fate to a creature within 15 feet of yourself. Once within the next hour when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can dismiss the Boon of Fate to reroll the test, potentially turning the failure into a success. A creature can have only one Boon of Fate at a time.

classFeature.name: Spell Weaving
entries: You have the uncanny ability to manipulate the weave of magic itself, which affords you a great flexibility in casting your spells. You can affect your spell slots using the options below.

entries.name: Creating Spell Slots.
entries: As a Bonus Action you can expend two spell slots of the same level to create one slot of the next level up. For example, you can expend two first level spell slots to create a second level slot. The created spell slots vanish at the end of a long rest.

entries.name: Recovering Spell Slots.
entries: As a Bonus Action, you can expend one spell slot of 2nd level or higher to recover two expended slots of a lower level. The sum of the recovered spell slot levels must be equal to or less than the level of the slot expended. For example, you can expend one third level slot to recover one first and one second level slot.

classFeature.name: Fate Weaver Subclass
entries: You gain a Fate Weaver subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Fate Weaver levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Fate Weaver level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|xphb} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Premonition
entries: When you roll Initiative, you can regain a number of expended Fate Dice equal to half your maximum number of Fate Dice (rounded down). Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Arcane Adaptability
entries: Whenever you finish a Short Rest, you can pluck at the threads and replace one of the level 1+ Fate Weaver spells you have prepared for your Spellcasting feature with another level 1+ spell from the {@filter Fate Weaver spell list.|spells|class=Fate Weaver (FW:R)}

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|xphb} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|xphb} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|xphb} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Straight from the Source
entries: Your abilities come not from a divinty, nor the primal spirits of the world, nor an arcane well of power, but from the fundamental reality that allows those things to exist in the first place. Whenever you change your list of prepared spells, you can choose two of your prepared spells from the {@filter Cleric|spells|class=Cleric}, {@filter Druid|spells|class=Druid}, or {@filter Wizard|spells|class=Wizard} spell lists.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an Epic Boon feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. {@feat Boon of Truesight|xphb} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Threadspinner
entries: Your ability to affect the fate of the world around you is unsurpassed by any other mortal. As a Bonus Action, you can enter a state of heightened power and gain the benefits below for 10 minutes. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Long Rest. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 7+ spell slot (no action required).

entries.name: Alter Reality.
entries: You have the Wish spell prepared, and if you cast Wish, you can choose the Roll Redo option without suffering any of the stress it would normally cause.

entries.name: Held Aloft.
entries: You are suspended in the air by the threads of fate. You have a Fly Speed of 30 feet, and can hover.

entries.name: Warp and Weft.
entries: Whenever you use a feature that expends Fate Dice, you expend one less die. Once you use this benefit, you can't do so again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of The Vizier
entries: {@i Peer Into the Web of Fate}

The web of fate is unfathomably complex, but you have learned what patterns to look for in order to tease secrets from its tangled branches. Whatever destiny awaits you and your companions, you are likely to see it coming.

subclassFeature.name: Vizier Spells
entries: When you reach a Fate Weaver level specified in the Vizier Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Vizier Spells
rows: {@spell Detect Magic|xphb}, {@spell Identify|xphb}, {@spell Augury|xphb}, {@spell See Invisibility|xphb}

subclassFeature.name: Innate Oracle
entries: Your view into to the web of fate allows you to effortlessly channel spells that reveal its secrets, and share those insights with others. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Guiding Hand.
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance|xphb} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of Fate Weaver cantrips. When you cast Guidance, its range is 30 feet instead of Touch.

entries.name: Minimal Exertion.
entries: When you cast a spell from the Divination school that has a casting time of an action, you can instead cast it as a Bonus Action.

entries.name: Self-Sufficient.
entries: When you cast a spell from the Divination school, you can do so without any Verbal components, and you can replace any Material components that are consumed by the spell or that have a cost specified in the spell with a Divination Focus, which is not consumed.

subclassFeature.name: Shared Insight
entries: You can share a small fraction of your view into the future with those touched by your magic. When a creature uses your Boon of Fate to reroll a failed D20 Test, they gain a bonus to the roll equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Oracular Judgment
entries: You can harness your connection to fate to uplift those who follow your guidance, and punish those who would endanger your path. Whenever you target a creature with an ability that expends one of your Fate Dice, you can choose to expend a spell slot and roll a number of Fate Dice equal to the slot's level. The targeted creature either gains {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} or takes psychic damage equal to the result (your choice). The Fate Dice you roll for this feature are not expended.

subclassFeature.name: Precognitive Reflex
entries: Your awareness of the future is so finely tuned that you can respond to events before they even happen. Once per turn, if you've already taken your Reaction, you can expend 1 Fate Die to take an additional Reaction. You can only take one Reaction per triggering effect.

subclassFeature.name: Paragon of Prophecy
entries: Your ability to see the future is unparalleled. You always have the {@spell Foresight|xphb} spell prepared, and you can cast it by expending 7 Fate Dice. Whenever you cast {@spell Foresight|xphb}, you can also choose to change its casting time to one Action instead of one minute. If you do so, its duration is only one minute. The Minimal Exertion benefit of your Innate Oracle feature does not affect this casting of the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of The Void
entries: {@i Know True Nothingness}

Something is wrong with you. Perhaps you have seen the end of time, had your soul disconnected from your body, or maybe you have been forgotten by fate altogether. Whatever the case, you are not so tightly bound by the rules of this world. You can slip through the cracks to see what lies beyond the edges of time and space, and tug at the fabric holding it all together. Though you must be careful which threads you pull, lest you unravel yourself completely.

subclassFeature.name: Void Spells
entries: When you reach a Fate Weaver level specified in the Void Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Void Spells
rows: {@spell Arms of Hadar|xphb}, {@spell Dissonant Whispers|xphb}, {@spell Darkness|xphb}, {@spell Phantasmal Force|xphb}

subclassFeature.name: Fateless
entries: Empty.

entries.name: Heart Stopper.
entries: You know the {@spell Chill Touch|xphb} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of Fate Weaver cantrips. When you cast Chill Touch, its range is 30 feet instead of Touch.

entries.name: Something cool and flavorful.
entries: Empty.

entries.name: Know Your End.
entries: You have Advantage on Death Saving Throws. Moreover, when you roll 16–20 on a Death Saving Throw, you gain the benefit of rolling a 20 on it.

subclassFeature.name: Call to the Void
entries: Empty.

subclassFeature.name: Empty Fortune
entries: Empty.

subclassFeature.name: Boon of the Void
entries: Empty.

subclassFeature.name: Inevitable End
entries: All things will face oblivion eventually, but you have the power to force them to that fate. You always have the {@spell Disintegrate|xphb} spell prepared. Whenever you cast {@spell Disintegrate|xphb} and the target fails its saving throw, you can expend Fate Dice to empower the spell. For each die you expend, the target takes an additional 10 force damage. Creatures and objects disintegrated by your casting of this spell unravel into nothingness. Not even dust remains.

item.name: Divination Focus
entries: A Divination Focus is an item or set of items used to glean hints about the future. A Fate Weaver can use such an item as a Spellcasting Focus. Below are a list of some common types of {@i Divination Focuses} and their method of use, but many other items and methods exist across many cultures.

items: A deck of illustrated cards which are shuffled and dealt to be read.
A shallow bowl of water into which needles are dropped.
Various bones, shells, dice, and other trinkets which are cast onto a surface.
A stone or metal bowl in which things are burnt and patterns are read from the ashes.

entries: {@b NEW RULE, WIP:} To use a Divination focus, you perform a ritual over the course of 1 minute.

{@b OLD RULE, TO BE REPLACED:} To use a Divination Focus, a 10-minute ritual is initiated, during which you ask a single question. You then make a spellcasting ability check, adding your proficiency bonus. For an accurate reading, a DC 12 check is required, or a DC determined by the DM based on the complexity of the question. More specific inquiries may result in a higher DC. Upon a successful check, you receive a vague response of up to 50 words, or a visual representation that you interpret. You may use a Divination Focus a number of times per day equal to your proficiency bonus, with all uses replenishing at dawn.

spell.name: Defer Destiny

time.condition: which you take when a creature you can see within range makes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Test}

entries: You pull the threads of fate away from one creature and hold them, preparing to re-thread them around another creature at a later time.
Record the number rolled by the triggering creature. The triggering creature must then reroll the {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Test} and use the new roll.

At any point while you maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}, you can choose a creature you can see within range (you can choose yourself) that is about to make a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Test}. Instead of rolling, the creature uses the number previously recorded and the spell ends.
If the spell ends before you select a second target, you take {@damage 4d8} force damage as the threads of fate tear away from your grasp.
